bioghist.p: Joseph Scotton Elkinton (1830-1905) was the son of Joseph and Mary (Nutt) Elkinton and was born at Tunesassa, N.Y. where his father taught school. In 1831 the family moved to Philadelphia. Joseph S. and his brother Thomas continued the soap business begun by their father. He married Malinda Patterson (1836-1920) in 1856 and they had four children: Mary Patterson, Joseph, Alfred Cope and William Tillman. Joseph S. Elkinton was a minister and very active member of the Philadelphia Meeting. He was especially interested in Native Americans and made religious journeys to the Senecas, Mennonites and Doukhobors. Nathaniel Peabody Rogers (1794-1846) graduated from Dartmouth in 1816, and practised law until 1838, when he established in Concord, New Hampshire, the "Herald of Freedom," a pioneer anti-slavery newspaper. He also wrote for the New York "Tribune" under the signature of "The Old Man of the Mountain." His fugitive writings were published, with a memoir, by the Reverend John Pierpont (Concord, 1847).

scopecontent.p: This is a miscellaneous collection of materials related to the Elkinton family. Materials include: records from the Western Monthly Meeting including list of births, deaths, and subscribers; miscellaneous maps and blueprints, including plans for the Friends Eastern burial ground; miscellaneous correspondence and legal documents from William T. Elkinton; research notes and lists of numerous Meetings in Pennsylvania and elsewhere; a receipt book for Joseph Elkinton and Sons (1851-1868); bills and receipts of the Institute of Colored Youth (1890-1891); and two unidentified commonplace books. The collection also contains materials related to Nathaniel Peabody Rogers including a journal (c. 1840), lectures, a scrapbook of newspaper articles written by Rogers, and a genealogical chart.
